author: ansgar.eth
content:
I updated the agenda for ACDE in 5.5h:
https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1808

author: ansgar.eth
content: depending on how much time Fusaka hard fork review takes, hopefully most of the call will focus on continuation of Glamsterdam scoping

author: ansgar.eth
content:
In particular, I created a grouping of Glamsterdam EL PFI'd EIPs by category, with CFI / DFI candidate annotations based on the client preferences and the discussion from last ACDE:
https://notes.ethereum.org/@ansgar/glamsterdam-el-pfi-eips

author: ansgar.eth
content: the plan is to go through these candidates first. For after that I have some general open questions listed on the agenda that hopefully help with further CFI / DFI clarifications

author: spencer_tb
content: I'm inclined to agree, although I'd rather we moved to world where we don't consider EIPs unless they have a champion. You could argue that a champion will form after a positive review of the proposal during ACD. For me if there is no active champion, then it feels hard to take the EIP seriously. This is all in the justice of saving precious time during development and CFI'ing EIPs. One of the reasons BAL has progressed so well in my opinion is because of the latter - the EELS spec progressed faster (& the tests too) üòâ

content: This post offers a brief overview of options for preserving scaling under state creation repricing related to EIP-8037: https://notes.ethereum.org/@anderselowsson/3-paradigms-for-state-creation-repricing

author: barnabasbusa
content: Totally agree, if an EIP can't attract a single champion for it, then its not worthwhile EIP.

author: hadriencroubois
content: You are somehow assuming all EIP author are coredev, or close enough to core dev to be familiar with the exact steps to champion an EIP. Basically that they are good lobbyists. This indirectly means that proposal by the wider community (including in particular people that build contracts and just see eth as an execution layer) are not worthwhile.

author: peter.davies
content: Anyone who complains that a worthwhile but unchampioned EIP is not being considered will be appointed champion. You have been warned!

author: hadriencroubois
content: <@243183686562873344> Is there any document anywhere that explain what it means to be a champion, and what is expected of one ?

author: hadriencroubois
content:
EIP-1 says
> In short, your role as the champion is to write the EIP using the style and format described below, shepherd the discussions in the appropriate forums, and build community consensus around the idea.
That is quite vague

author: hadriencroubois
content: How is an individual, that is not a core dev, expected to "build community consensus" ?

author: trent_vanepps
content:
while i readily admit that core development requires a lot of context to operate properly within - we can't escape the fact that core devs and bandwidth are scarce resources

the alternative scenario to your prompt is that "core devs" (which are not a monolithic organization) are obligated to appoint a champion/case manager for every EIP (in the extreme) or more EIPs than there are people for. and by extension overwhelm the ACD/scoping process

author: nero_eth
content: 6SS is spec'ed and prototyped, it has been empirically analyzed (as much as could be done already without having it run on an actual devnet) and there is broad community consensus. It's further than 90% of EIPs. Don't see why formalities should block it.

author: hadriencroubois
content:
What I'm trying to say is that I think people beyound the core devs should be able to have the protocol evolve. I believe there is value in EIP that come from users (being a user and an EIP author I'm clearly biased here).

I'm not saying the core dev should do all the work, and allocate their limited ressources to lead stuff I (or other) proposed, but at the same time it would be great if all the burden doesn't go on the user's sholder. I don't think its realistic to ask a non-core-dev to implement the EIP in multiple client, write the test, and build community consensus. 

As a user of the network, it feel like the expectation are so high that (almost) no evolution comes from our end, and that everything is the result of ideas EF researchers and core devs have extensivelly discussed over coffee. Not that what they do is bad, its great! But its missing a lot of the "user experience" of people building on top of the execution layer.

author: jtraglia
content: I would not consider 6SS spec'd right now btw. It's [still just a PR](https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/4484) which needs more work to get merged. The EIP's champion needs to spend some time fixing/improving things. Only after that PR is merged would I consider it spec'd.

author: nero_eth
content: ok, yeah, this is fair. Practically speaking, is quite far already wrt being an PFI'ed EIP. It was implemented into at least 2 clients and run on a local devent.

author: nero_eth
content: One could argue the same about other EIPs that aren't rebased on top of glamsterdam already. Some are quite far, but none is actually done.

author: jtraglia
content: I don't think anyone is claiming that those are spec'd though.

author: nero_eth
content: But we're still SFI'ing them? IIrc, SFI i bound to being specc'ed.

author: nero_eth
content:
Imo it's fine to not have a definition for it. Everyone is free to champion an EIP, or push for an EIP without championing it.
Defining "champion" and forcing it into some tight boundaries isn't productive and just complicates the process.
